question: What events happen twice each day in the tide cycle?

content.source_1: Earth rotates once about its axis roughly every 24 hours, creating a repeating day–night cycle for surface observers.
content.source_2: At latitudes outside the Arctic and Antarctic Circles (|latitude| < about 66.5°), the sun rises above and sets below the horizon at least once during every 24-hour period throughout the year.
content.source_3: Dakar, Senegal lies at approximately 14.7° N latitude, well outside the polar circles.
content.source_4: During polar night, locations north of the Arctic Circle can go for many consecutive days to months without any sunrise.
content.source_5: Tromsø, Norway (about 69.7° N) is north of the Arctic Circle and undergoes polar night from late November to mid-January.
content.source_6: In mid-December, the sun does not rise above the horizon in Tromsø, despite Earth’s continuous rotation.
